text.headline:
Vortex
2005 - 2015
text.text: Vortex is a little story of success: today, 10 years after its foundation by two PhD in Atmospheric Physics and a self-taught IT expert, the company has offices in 3 continents and serves users from 149 countries

media.caption:
Pep Moreno installing a met. mast during a measurement campaign in Northern Spain.
Early 90’s

text.headline: A young company made up of old experts
text.text: Vortex was born in Barcelona on September 19th 2005, but its team’s background is much older: the accumulated experience in the wind industry of its members goes back 25 years ago

media.caption:
David Saez at first Vortex cluster.
Early 2006

text.headline: Just a simple, powerful idea
text.text: The foundational approach of the Vortex service was simple: remote atmospheric modeling, on-line. With the aim to 'bring the power of a supercomputer to your fingerprints' in mind, our first cluster was set up in 2006

media.caption: Professor Josep Calbó returning from the Universitat de Girona with his, at that time 2 years old, daughter. Late 2006

text.headline: Research that faces the real world
text.text: We love research: half of Vortex employees hold a PhD and we keep active links with several research institutes since our first collaboration with the Universitat de Girona in 2006. However, the continuos feedback from our users makes us always keep research tight to the real world 'imperfections'

media.caption:
One of the first drafts of the future Vortex Interface.
Early 2007

text.headline: Complex modeling at one-click distance
text.text: From its first sketches in 2007, the philosophy of Vortex Interface was to reduce the complexity of the atmospherice modeling to intuitive user website actions. Since the beginning, user manuals and courses were strictly forbiden

media.caption:
Pau Casso at Longs Peak (Colorado) after attending the 9th WRF Users' Workshop in Boulder, CO.
July 2008

text.headline: A cloud (service) with solid foundations
text.text: Vortex is not a large company but we are not at all alone: since our first contact with WRF in 2006, our core technology relies on a collaborative code developed through the effort of a community of tenths of thousands of users
